Summary:
The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus who presented with respiratory failure due to an ESBL-producing Klebsiella pneumonia. He was admitted to the ICU and has been on non-invasive ventilation since November 11th. The patient had an episode of respiratory distress/hypoxemia that resolved with nebulized bronchodilators and repositioning. A chest X-ray showed mainstem mucous plugging, which was addressed and repeated X-rays were planned. 

The patient has multiple medical issues including hypernatremia, dyspnea, impaired balance, impaired knowledge, impaired muscle performance, hypertension, hyperglycemia, impaired skin integrity, and acute renal failure. The patient's blood glucose levels have been elevated but are being managed with D5W (5% dextrose in water). 

The patient is still experiencing poor mental status, which may be due to ongoing ICU delirium. His renal function is improving, and he is being treated for ESBL Klebsiella bacteremia/pneumonia with meropenem. He also has GPC bacteremia being treated with vancomycin. 

The patient's hypertension is being managed with multiple antihypertensive medications, including diltiazem, metoprolol, clonidine, and enalapril. Additionally, he is being given prn hydralazine for further control of his blood pressure. 

Other issues such as tachycardia/S

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   - s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - F/u ID recs
   - get cultures daily  (until cultures negative x48 hours, per ID)
   - daily CXR
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Daily CXR
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   - improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened after
   lasix given for resp distress
   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral

   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU given tenuous respiratory status.

Summary:
The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus who presented to the hospital with septic shock secondary to Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia. He has been in the ICU for several weeks and has developed multiple complications.

1. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, leading to hypernatremia. This could be due to inadequate water intake or excessive water loss. The patient's daily fluid intake needs to be assessed, and measures should be taken to increase free water administration.

2. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and requires high levels of oxygen, suggesting acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Weaning off the ventilator may be challenging due to ongoing episodes of respiratory distress. Frequent suctioning, nebulizer treatments, and respiratory toilet are necessary.

3. Altered mental status: The patient's prolonged intubation and sedation, along with ongoing infection, may have contributed to his altered mental status. It is important to monitor the patient closely, and if there is no improvement, further evaluation with head CT, EEG monitoring, and assessment of the airway may be necessary.

4. Acute renal failure: The patient initially had elevated creatinine levels and was oliguric. However, urine output has improved, and the patient's glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is likely normal now. Renal recommendations include maintaining a daily urine output of more than 2 liters and avoiding

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus (DM) who presented to the hospital after experiencing septic shock with Staphylococcus aureus (Staph) pneumonia and bacteremia. The patient's condition was complicated by acute renal failure (ARF) and tachycardia. He remains intubated but is off pressors since October 28th.

The patient has several medical complications that require attention:

1. Septic shock/Pneumonia: The patient was initially treated with vancomycin and cefepime empirically due to MSSA in the sputum and blood. Subsequently, meropenem was added for GNR in the blood. The patient's status improved with this broad-spectrum antibiotic regimen.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and requires high levels of oxygen, suggesting acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He was extubated on November 10th but continues to experience episodes of respiratory distress and requires frequent suctioning, nebulizers, and respiratory toilet.

3. Altered Mental Status (AMS): The patient's prolonged intubation and sedation (>3 weeks) along with ongoing infection are likely contributing to his altered mental status. Toxic-metabolic encephalopathy is suspected, and if no improvement, further evaluation such as head CT, EEG monitoring, and assessment of ammonia levels may be considered.

4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's initial elevated creatinine level improved with increased urine output and likely normal glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Renal function is currently stable, and the patient is advised to maintain a daily urine output of more than 2 liters.

5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, possibly due to dehydration. Free water flushes have been increased, and D5W is being administered to correct this electrolyte imbalance.

6. Hypertension: The patient has persistent hypertension despite antihypertensive medications. Clonidine patch, diltiazem, metoprolol, and amlodipine have been prescribed. Lisinopril has also been started and titrated to effect.

7. Diabetes Mellitus (DM): The patient's blood sugars have been poorly controlled, but this could be attributed to recent interventions. Insulin therapy has been initiated.

8. Tachycardia/Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has experienced episodes of tachycardia and atrial fibrillation. Adenosine has been used to manage SVT, and diltiazem has been prescribed for rate control.

9. Rash: The patient developed a drug rash, possibly due to cefepime, which has been discontinued. Topical creams have been applied to the affected areas.

10. Elevated Troponin: The patient's troponin levels were elevated, indicating possible myocardial ischemia. However, cardiac enzymes are no longer trending, and ACS treatment has been discontinued.

11. Mild LFT Elevation: The patient's liver function tests were mildly elevated but have improved and stabilized.

In summary, the patient's medical complications include septic shock/pneumonia, hypoxic respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute renal failure, hypernatremia, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, tachycardia/atrial fibrillation, rash, elevated troponin,

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus who presented to the hospital with septic shock and pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus. He was intubated and received broad-spectrum antibiotics, which improved his condition. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation but is now off pressors. He has had episodes of respiratory distress and requires frequent suctioning and nebulizer treatments. His mental status is altered likely due to prolonged intubation and sedation.

The patient has several medical complications, including hypernatremia, respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute kidney injury, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and an elevated troponin level. He has also experienced tachycardia and atrial fibrillation. A drug rash was initially observed but has improved.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Hypernatremia: The patient's high sodium levels need to be managed. D5W should be given at 120cc/hr x1L, and electrolytes should be checked.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient requires ongoing respiratory support with frequent suctioning and nebulizer treatments. Weaning of FiO2 and PEEP is recommended.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's prolonged intubation and sedation may be contributing to his altered mental status. Monitoring and further evaluation are necessary.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's renal function has improved, but close monitoring and follow

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**].
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function, also added
   vancomycin on [**11-10**] for GPC
   - s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - F/u ID recs
   - daily CXR
   - d/c daily  cultures given negative x48 hours, per ID
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   -Meropenem, vancomycin as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.
   - F/u renal recs, no HD and HD line removed
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Hypernatremia
   - improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr overnight but then worsened after
   lasix given for resp distress
   - Increased free H20 flushes to 300cc q4h
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Continue hydralazine 500mg Q6 hrs, can consider decreasing when ACEI
   uptitrated.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - star lisinopril and titrate to effect
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, will readdress in AM
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults, HD per
   renal
 holding for now given improved renal fxn. Calculate free water
   deficit given hypernatremia
 give D5W at 120cc/hr x1L, check pm lytes
   and urine lytes (hyperna could be contributing to AMS).
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral

He required intubation and mechanical ventilation but was successfully extubated on [**11-10**]. The patient has a history of altered mental status, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), hypernatremia, hypertension, and hyperglycemia. He also had episodes of tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and a drug rash. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.9C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99% on high-flow nasal cannula, and a sinus rhythm. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and lactate levels, as well as elevated troponin and liver enzymes. Imaging studies show diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray and widened mediastinum. The patient's medical team has initiated appropriate antibiotic therapy and continues to manage his multiple comorbidities and complications.

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), GNR in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**], growing
   Pseudomonas and Klebsiella.  s/p removal of aline, HD line, TLC
   - Per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days Meropenem since first
   negative blood culture = course should be from [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg
   staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a contaminant).
   - Meropenem re-dosed for pt
s improved renal function
   - Continue vancomycin, started on [**11-10**] for GPC, 7 day course, d/c [**11-16**]
   - F/u ID recs
   - hold on daily CXR given continued improvement
   - d/c daily  cultures given negative x48 hours, per ID
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   # Volume Status:  Hypernatremia improved with 1/2D5 at 240 ml/hr
   overnight but then worsened after lasix given for resp distress.
   Resolved, now becoming hyponatremic.
   - Hold IVF today; no D5W
   - Decrease free H20 flushes from 300cc q4h PM of [**11-14**] to 200cc q4h
   - Consider U lytes if hyponatremia worsens, though likely [**1-4**] volume
   overload
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L; f/u
   Renal recs
   - Assess I/O and use Lasix for diuresis if necessary in PM
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
   - Decrease Hydralazine from 50mg Q6 hrs to 25mg q6h
   - Consider increasing Lisinopril from 10mg to 20mg daily tomorrow if
   patient
s BP high with decrease of Hydral
   - Continue clonidine patch 0.3; titrate down once Hydralazine is weaned
   off
   - Continue Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily.
   - Cont Dilt and Metoprolol
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam (started on [**11-11**])
   - Consider initiating Celexa 20mg daily for anxiety with goal of
   d/c
ing Clonazepam once SSRI becomes effective
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars poorly controlled but pt on D5 for hypernatremia
   yesterday.
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS, increase SSI for sugars in 200
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s MS is
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement can
   consider head CT, EEG monitoring and AMS w/u.
   - Monitor for now.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.  Resolved Cr, HD line
   removed.
   - F/u renal recs
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - Continue diltiazem 30mg qid
   - Continue metoprolol at 125mg tid
   - Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily.
   - anxiety component of tachy/HTN seems apparent, start 1mg [**Hospital1 **]
   clonazepam
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds, speech & swallow and PT consults
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number
   (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: ICU for today as profoundly weak; ideally discharge
   directly to rehab if possible given patient
s insurance

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus who presented to the ICU after experiencing septic shock with Staphylococcus pneumonia. The patient had ARF (acute renal failure), tachycardia, and hypertension. He was intubated but is now off pressors and remains intubated. The patient's current medications include vancomycin, meropenem, famotidine, and clonidine patch.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which is a high sodium level in the blood. This condition can cause dehydration, increased thirst, and neurological symptoms.

2. Dyspnea: The patient has dyspnea or shortness of breath. This could be due to respiratory failure or pneumonia.

3. Impaired Knowledge: The patient's prolonged intubation and sedation may have led to impaired mental status or delirium.

4. Impaired Muscle Performance: Prolonged immobility and bed rest can lead to muscle weakness and impaired muscle performance.

5. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which needs to be managed to prevent complications such as heart attack or stroke.

6. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which can cause respiratory distress and infection.

7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood sugars are poorly controlled, indicating hyperglycemia.

8. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's prolonged

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 37-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus who presented to the ICU after experiencing septic shock and pneumonia. The patient remains intubated but is off pressors since October 28th. He has a history of ARF (acute renal failure), hypertension, hypoxic respiratory failure, altered mental status, and hypernatremia. The patient's current vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5C, heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 122/67 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on high-flow nasal cannula. 

The patient's recent lab results show normal WBC count, Hct, and Plt levels. However, his Cr levels were initially elevated at 7.8 but have since improved. His glucose levels are poorly controlled, but he is currently receiving insulin therapy. Other notable lab results include elevated TCO2, CK, Troponin-T, ALT/AST, and LDH levels, with decreased Albumin, Ca++, and PO4 levels. His imaging shows improved aeration bilaterally and decreased haziness, with an improved left lung base opacity.

The patient's assessment and plan include treatment for MSSA (methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus) in the sputum and blood, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas in

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 37-year-old man with diabetes mellitus who is currently experiencing respiratory failure due to an infection caused by ESBL Klebsiella. He has been admitted to the ICU and is being treated with antibiotics and aggressive pulmonary toilet. The patient also has bacteremia from GPC and is receiving vancomycin treatment. He has shown some improvement in muscle strength and mental status but still exhibits weakness, impaired skin integrity, hypertension, and hyperglycemia. The patient is on multiple medications for hypertension and tachycardia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, which can lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation if not properly managed.
2. Infection: The presence of ESBL Klebsiella pneumonia and bacteremia increases the risk of secondary infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-related bloodstream infections.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension needs to be closely monitored and managed to prevent complications like hypertensive crisis or end-organ damage.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's high blood glucose levels indicate uncontrolled diabetes, which may increase the risk of diabetic complications and poor wound healing.
5. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity could lead to pressure ulcers or infections if not addressed properly.
6. ICU Myopathy: The patient's weakness and impaired muscle performance suggest the possibility of ICU-acquired myopathy

   37 y/o with DM presents from OSH after presenting in septic shock with
   Staph PNA / bacteria with a course complicated by ARF and tachycardia,
   currently remains intubated but off pressors since [**2117-10-28**]. Staph in
   blood/sputum (OSH), Klebsiella in blood, klebsiella and pseudomonas in
   sputum.  Has gone into SVT (wide complex) in the past, resolved with
   adenosine.
   .
   # Septic shock/Pneumonia: BP stable off pressors. Culture data positive
   for MSSA in the sputum and blood early in OSH course.  CT scan with L >
   R infiltrates, but no sign of empyema. We broadened antibiotics
   empirically with vanc and cefepime with improvement in the patient
   status.  CT scan did show fluid in sinuses and multi-focal pneumonia
   but no other clear source.  Treated for flu although DFA neg x 2 in
   OSH, with another negative DFA here we stopped Tamiflu.  Elevated mixed
   venous Sat elevated at 84% and mottled appearance most suggestive of
   septic etiology. CVP at 15, hypovolemia unlikely. Robust BP despite
   tachycardia, high mixed venous, and preserved EF on OSH ECHO suggests
   against cardiogenic shock. Given negative urine legionalla and
   prolonged QTc at times, we have avoided using a fluoroquinolone.
   Currently, we are treating for the MSSA found on blood/sputum from OSH,
   Klebsiella pneumoniae and pseudomonas in the sputum from [**Hospital1 19**], GNR in
   blood and radiographic evidence of PNA.  TTE normal, no signs of
   vegetations.  Gram negative rods in blood culture from [**11-1**], growing
   Pseudomonas and Klebsiella.  s/p removal of A.line, HD line, TLC
   - On meropenem; per ID consult: should treat with 14 total days
   Meropenem since first negative blood culture = course should be from
   [**11-5**] to [**11-19**] (coag neg staph on [**11-9**] and [**11-10**] likely staph epi and a
   contaminant).
   - Completed 7 day course of vancomycin on [**11-16**]
   - F/u ID recs
   - CXR tomorrow (Qod CXRs)
   - f/u sputum cxr, sensitivities, speciation
   - prn Tylenol for fevers
   .
   # Hypoxic Resp failure: Bilateral infiltrates on CXR and high oxygen
   requirement suggestive of ARDS.  Did not have any weaning of his vent
   setting yesterday, other than decreased RR to counteract alkalosis.
   Weaned FiO2 to 40% and now with PEEP of 8.  Extubated on [**11-10**] (s/p
   precedex, benzo use to help with anxiety while intubated).
   Significantly resolving. Continues to have episodes of respiratory
   disress and requires frequent suctioning, nebs and respiratory toilet.
   NAC nebs x1 day to help prevent mucus plugging.
   -Meropenem as above
   - Wean O2 as tolerated
 doing well on 2L NC
   - Frequent suctioning and CPT as tolerated
   .
   # Volume Status: Monitoring hypernatremia. No D5 yesterday.
   - Cont free water flushes 200cc q4h
   - Consider U lytes if hyponatremia worsens, though likely [**1-4**] volume
   overload
   - Per renal recs, will give PRN Lasix to keep total daily UOP > 2L; f/u
   Renal recs
   - Assess I/O and use Lasix for diuresis if necessary in PM
   - Re check electrolytes this pm
   .
   # Hypertension
 currently overly well-controlled. Will discontinue
   Dilt.
   - Hydralazine and clonidine patch discontinued yesterday.
   - Continue Lisinopril 10mg Qday, Metop 150 TID
   .
   # DM: Blood sugars better controlled with CBGs 120-150s
   - Glargine 50 QD and continue ISS,
   .
   OTHER STABLE ISSUES
   .
   #Altered mental status:  Given patient
s prolonged intubation and
   sedation (>3 weeks) as well as ongoing infection, think pt
s AMS was
   likely due to toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.   If no improvement or
   worsening of encephalopathy, can consider head CT, EEG monitoring and
   LP.
   - Overall, much improved today ([**11-17**]), and pt is oriented,
   interactive, verbal, appropriate.
   .
   # ARF: Cr initially elevated at 7.8 and pt was oliguric, while patient
   was in septic shock. Urine output increasing considerably over past few
   days and pt
s GFR is likely normal at this point.  Resolved Cr, HD line
   removed.
   - F/u renal recs
   - Cr stabilizing at 0.9 to 1 with excellent UOP.
   .
   # Tachycardia/ AFib: appeared sinus on arrival, then through his course
   had couple runs of tachycardia that appeared to be Afib with aberrancy
   that were self-limited and well-tolerated.   OSH EKG with RBBB as
   recently as [**10-26**], and reports of atrial fibrillation requiring
   treatment with diltiazem.  Several days ago, went into AFib w/ RVR
   during dialysis.  Treated w/ lopressor 10, dilt 20 IV and dilt PO60.
   Converted back to sinus after 1-2 hours. Atrial irritation believed due
   to IJ that was too deep, now pulled back.  Cause of aberrant SVT during
   second HD session likely due to intracellular shifts, although cause
   not clear.   24 hour amiodarone has completed. Patient with persistent
   tachycardia and hypertension for 2 days. Tachycardia resolved x 5
   7 days as of [**11-14**].
   - Adenosine at bedside in case of SVT
   - dc Dilt today
   - Continue metoprolol at 150 tid
   - Watch hemodynamics and rhythm; on telemetry
   .
   # Rash on back, abdomen, thighs: appears consistent with a drug rash,
   could be Vanc or Cefepime, but statistically Cefepime would be more
   likely. Discontinued vanc/cefepime on [**10-31**]; now on meropenem. Improved
   clinically, less erythematous.
   - Monitor
   - Clobetasol [**Hospital1 **] 0.05% for abdomen
   - Clotrimazole/hydro groin cream for rash
   .
   # Elevated Troponin: CK elevated, CKMB flat. most likely demand
   ischemia in setting of shock and persistent tachycardia vs elevated [**1-4**]
   renal failure. ACS given age unlikely, d/c ACS treatment including ASA,
   heparin gtt, plavix. No longer trending cardiac enzymes.
   .
   # Mild LFT elevation: likely [**1-4**] prolonged hypotension.
   Improved/stable.
   - Continue to trend LFTs
   - Limit tylenol to 2 gm daily; changed standing Tylenol to PRN
   .
   FEN; Lytes prn, tube feeds for now, will re-consult speech & swallow
   given pt
s improved strength and mental status
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: PICC line, peripheral
   Code:  Full code confirmed
   Communication: With the patient and his Mother, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 11771**]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11772**]. HCP name/number (ICU RN) on whiteboard in room.
   Disposition: Call out to floor today
Summary:
The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus who presented from outside the hospital with septic shock and Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia. The patient's course has been complicated by acute renal failure and tachycardia, and he remains intubated but off pressors since October 28th. Cultures have grown MSSA in the sputum and blood, as well as Klebsiella pneumoniae in the blood. The patient was treated empirically with vancomycin and cefepime, and then later switched to meropenem based on the sensitivity results. The patient's current medications include meropenem, lisinopril, metoprolol, glargine, and ISS. The patient is also on prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin and a proton pump inhibitor.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure ranging from 125/76 mmHg to 140/85 mmHg, a heart rate of 72 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99% on a nasal cannula, and a temperature of 36.4C. The patient's physical examination reveals fairly clear to bilaterally auscultated lungs, trace edema bilaterally in the lower extremities, and 2+ pitting edema bilaterally in the hands. The patient's mental status has improved, and he is alert, oriented

The patient is a 37-year-old male with diabetes mellitus presenting from the outdoors with a history of septic shock secondary to Staphylococcus pneumonia, acute renal failure, and tachycardia. He remains intubated but off pressors since October 28th. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia caused by MSSA, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and pseudomonas in the sputum. He has also been treated for influenza with negative DFA tests twice, and his Tamiflu was stopped. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4C (97.6F), heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 125/76 mmHg to 148/85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and sinus rhythm. The patient's weight is currently 113 kg and height is 69 inches. 

The patient has been prescribed various medications including meropenem, vancomycin, heparin sodium, and others. His fluid balance shows a total intake of 4888 mL and total output of 3180 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 1708 mL. His laboratory results indicate elevated levels of sodium (270 K/uL), glucose (243 mg/dL), and troponin-T (550). Other lab values are within normal range.

The patient's physical examination reveals no murmurs, obesity with bruising

- The patient remained intubated but was off pressors since October 28th.
- The patient had a history of septic shock and tachycardia, with a previous episode of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) that resolved with adenosine.
- The patient had multi-focal pneumonia and fluid in the sinuses but no clear source of infection.
- The patient was treated for influenza despite negative DFA tests.
- The patient's mixed venous saturation was elevated at 84%, suggesting a septic etiology.
- The patient had high blood sugar levels, which were poorly controlled.
- The patient had altered mental status due to prolonged intubation, sedation, and ongoing infection, potentially causing toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.
